The Economist Asks: "Will there be a new Prime Minister of the United Kingdom before 1 October 2018?" Forecast: No: ﻿100% | Yes: someone from the Conservative party: 0% | Yes: someone from the Labour Party: 0% | Yes: someone from a party other than Labour or Conservative Parties: 0% To address this question, I contend that it is vital to focus on the average span between the announcement of the snap election and when the election is held. Thus, as it is uncertain whether an election announcement will come from British Prime Minster Teresa May before the end of September, ﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿I completely disregarded its influence on the answer to this question. I posit that elections will not be held before the end date of this forecast, as historically, the time between the announcement of snap elections and the date for the elections is greater than 12 days, the time left in the month of September. When Teresa May held snap elections in 2017, she announced the snap election approximately two months before the election was held. (https://www.businessinsider.com/heres-why-the-prime-minister-of-the-uk-has-the-power-to-call-a-snap-election-2017-4). Teresa May provided ample time for the parties to select candidates and for the candidates to be considered. It can be assumed that she will afford a similar length of time between a snap election and its announcement. Similarly, when Tony Blair called for snap elections in 2005, he provided over three weeks of time between its announcement and the election itself. (http://www.cnn.com/2005/WORLD/europe/04/13/uk.blair.manifesto/) Additionally, if Teresa May resigns, the election process will similarly take over three weeks as it did when David Cameron resigned in 2016. (https://www.ft.com/content/cda2a764-37c3-11e6-a780-b48ed7b6126f)

Barniers has not suggested that the EU is likely to agree to the Chequers Proposal in the next 6 to 8 weeks if both sides are realistic, he was referring to the Withdrawal Agreement which according to the EU timetable was to have been agreed in October (2017 not 2018) and was agreed in principal on 8th Dec 2017. Boris Johnson would like to be PM, but I doubt that the Conservative MPs would vote to get rid of Mrs May and choose Johnson unopposed in the next 4 weeks. Any contest for PM would probably take at least 2 weeks to organise after Mrs May was deposed, and it would probably take a week to depose Mrs May. So really there is only time if the process started in the next few days. This is in spite of the Brexit process seeming to be hitting a brick wall, as the Conservative Party and the Brexiteers seem to have differing views on how to proceed, let alone who should lead them. The Chequers Plan seems to succeeded in uniting  the public, MPs and the EU in that almost everyone agrees they don't want it. Some Brexiteer MPs want No Deal (aka WTO rules) in spite of the WTO pointing out the UK is very unlikely to get agreement from other WTO members in time for March 2019. Its also almost certain that MPs would block a No Deal. Other Brexiteers are still demanding that the UK negotiate a Canada + type deal, claiming that force of will and belief will produce a magic solution to the Irish Border problem. There is no sign of either the UK Government trying to negotiate a Canada + type FTA, or the EU accepting that it can solve the Irish Border Issue, and even if there was it would seem very unlikely that it could be full negotiated  by December 2020 (the end of the implementation period).
The Chequers Plan seems dead in the water. Which leaves  Norway + (EEA + EFTA  + EU Single Market) either as an interim solution until another FTA can be negotiated that would solve the Irish Border Problem (i.e. the Magic Potion is found) or as a permanent state for the UK. The final option is that the UK changes its mind and stays in the EU after all.

Parliament is in recess now until 4 September.  For all (reasonable) intents and purposes, this means that May is safe from a Vote of No Confidence until Tuesday 4th of September.  Assuming there is a successful VoNC against her on that day, she would have until Tuesday 18th September to regain the confidence of the House.  If she cannot do that, an election would need to be called with a minimum 5 week ("25 working day") dissolution of Parliament beforehand. In short, there will NOT be another election before 1 October, so there is no realistic chance of YES, LABOUR. I am not even sure whether it is possible for there to be a leadership spill in the Conservatives while Parliament is in recess.  Technically, the 1922 Committee only meets while Parliament is in session.  I guess it is theoretically possible, but it would be organisationally a nightmare, with parliamentarians scattered across the country (and around the world). More likely is a leadership challenge once Parliament returns (4-13 September), or at the Conservative Party Conference (30 September - 3 October) - though generally May's support among the wider party membership seems fairly strong - https://yougov.co.uk/news/2018/07/09/leave-voting-conservative-party-members-are-starti/ Regardless, the prospects of a YES, CONSERVATIVE resolution is significantly lower now than it was while Parliament was still in session.
Who? BJ lacks the support he needs in the party to replace her and Labor is too deeply divided between its left and far-left to mount a coherent challenge.

I’ve been giving this a bit more thought and am building on my earlier post and have changed some of my judgements. I am now going to approach this from the point of outcomes.  The desirable outcome (which may nevertheless be suboptimal) in the current Brexit process is a deal which lets the UK avoid leaving the EU without a deal i.e. the UK needs to leave with a deal. And as any final deal has to be endorsed by parliament, the deal has to be acceptable to parliament.  While the bulk of parliamentarians are Remainers, the currently highly fragmented nature of parliament, which is still structured on party lines means that the more extreme Brexiteers (i.e. those preferring to leave without a deal) have a hugely disproportionate say within the Conservative party. Essentially they can threaten the prime minister with her downfall by challenging her leadership pretty much on a whim. It is they who are currently driving the process. In light of her severely depleted political capital (she must be hanging on by her fingertips) she is acutely vulnerable. As her Chequers plan of last week is now in tatters, it is not clear where she goes from here as it will not make it through parliament. This leaves Teresa May in a significant bind: she can’t move forward (where to? She has just given it her best shot), but neither can she move back (either to a more Remain stance or a more Brexiteer stance as the opposing stance immediately undermines her; her fate is no longer in her control).  So, in order to neutralize the really rather few ‘No Deal’ Brexiteers, parliament has to cohere in some form. One way of doing this would be via a government of national unity; another way would be under a Conservative leader (as it is they who are currently in power) who more genuinely is able to bring a more acceptable deal to party than Teresa May was able to.  So the possible options facing the country are:  1) Teresa May carries on as is - to nowhere. As things are she is not going to get her plan through parliament so this seems a pointless strategy. She may just hang on in the hope that something changes over the summer (to speculate on what would take too long here). However, because she is a very resilient woman I am now suggesting there is a low to medium (30%) probability of her carrying on until October.  2) Teresa May realises that she is at a dead-end and resigns to be replaced by either a Conservative Brexiteer (which will be followed by a Conservative meltdown as Remainer Conservatives won't stand for it so are likely to vote against him or her in parliament leading to an election and probable Labour government) or Remainer (in which case more of the same as under May, say for another 6 months); a Brexiteer replacement is unlikely as there isn't enough support for one. I think there is a quite high probability (65%) probability of this happening.   3) May may be forced from power if there are elections should the Conservative Brexiteers bring down the government which, counter-productively, it looks like they are increasingly inclined to do should she not bend to their will, which she cant knowing that any deal which appeals to them wont making it through parliament. But bringing her down would be counter-productive as it would lead to a Labour government and the Conservative Brexiteers would lose control of the process, so it would seem unlikely. But as a last resort, who knows? I wouldn't rule out Labour promising them a full Brexit in order to bring this about – I have seen greater treachery in politics and for Brexiteers this is an existential issue. I have lowered the probability of this happening to 5%. Low, but possible.  Below are the two outcomes that could lead follow from the above scenarios: 1) A government of national unity is formed which looks unlikely as Labour front bench are unlikely to support the idea as is Teresa May as it would imply a lack of confidence in her leadership; so, this is only likely to happen after Teresa May as gone.  2) A referendum is offered with two options: a hard Brexit or soft Brexit; remaining is no longer an option. A referendum is only likely to happen after Teresa May has gone. My best guess is that Teresa May resigns (pushed or jumps) and a Remainer Conservative takes her place ushering in either a government of national unity and/or referendum. The only circumstance under which she is likely to stay is if parliament were to rally round in the belief that No Deal is increasingly probable. As the clock is ticking, something will give very soon. My belief is that as May is the blocking point, she will move or be moved (thanks to those grey men in grey suits).

A modification to my forecast calculated here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/756756 This is keeping in mind that any leadership challenge ideally needs to occur "while the iron is hot", and the iron is rapidly cooling after the resignations last week, and the deadline of parliamentary recess rapidly approaches.  Hence the probabilities below reflect numbers "here and now", and reflect a narrower window for those numbers to change in future. WILL THERE BE A LEADERSHIP CHALLENGE? 
No challenge so far, despite May just losing a vote on the floor, means that we can be more confident that there are NOT the numbers in the Tory party room to spill May ... and everyone knows it.  Besides who would replace her?  The Remainers know that any alternative will likely be even more pro-Brexit; the Brexiteers know that they are getting most of what they want with May in place ... so I am not convinced that there is any solid bloc who want her to go! Some numbers around pro-Brexit Tories contemplating a leadership challenge? (All are my "best guess" ...) Less than 48 members (p= 0.10) -> insufficient to launch a leadership challenge. 
48 to 100-ish members (p= 0.80) -> could launch a challenge, but would certainly lose, which would be self-defeating. 
100-ish to 158 members (p= 0.09) -> within spitting distance of winning a challenge and might consider launching a challenge then gathering enough support to win a close ballot. 
159 or more members (p= 0.01) -> will launch a challenge ASAP, and be confident of winning. The 100-158 bracket will more likely than not launch a challenge (p= 0.65).  However, they are unlikely to win (p= 0.30). Putting this together ... 
10%: Weak support, no challenge possible. 
80%: Weak support, challenge deferred pending better chances. 
4% (0.09 * 0.65 * 0.70): Moderate support, decision to launch challenge, which is unsuccessful. 
2% (0.09 * 0.65 * 0.30): Moderate support, decision to launch challenge, which is successful -> YES, CONSERVATIVE. 
3% (0.09 * 0.35): Moderate support, decision to NOT launch challenge. 
1%: Strong support, successful challenge launched -> YES, CONSERVATIVE. Overall, that is 5% that May will fall to a leadership challenge in the near future. WILL THERE BE A VOTE OF NO CONFIDENCE? A SUCCESSFUL ONE? 
If May is NOT overthrown (p= 0.95), what is the chance that 3 Tories will support a Labour VoNC ... AND then continue to withhold confidence from May until the government falls ... AND have the election held before 1 October?? Best guess I have is 2%, in which case -> YES, LABOUR.

No action taken yet to unseat May, but The Times front page headline states: “Back me or we hold an election, PM told rebels”. So, whilst as time moves forward it seems less likely that there will be time for a leadership change before the date specified, May’s leadership remains heavily in question. As such, I’ve lowered my % that it will change, but not as quickly as I could have.

After caving in to hard liner Brexiteers on Monday, Theresa May survived a vote in which 12 pro-EU tories voted for an amendment that she opposed that would have created a frictionless free trade agreement by January 2019 or the UK would have to be in the EU customs union. She won this vote by six votes, five of them coming from Labor and it lost by 307-301. She also backed off of her suggestion that they adjourn early for summer break because she would have lost that vote. If there is a vote of no confidence, she would have 14 days in which to win the vote of confidence, or a general election is held in two months. Unless something else blows up, it looks like she should survive until they go off for summer break next Tuesday and therefore likely to remain PM until October.

An early summer recess with MPs returning in September would leave a very small window of time for the government to collapse, or for May’s leadership to be successfully challenged.
https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jul/16/sending-mps-on-early-holiday-could-make-all-the-difference-for-may

Jacob Rees-Mogg, the chairman of the ERG, told the BBC “we’ll have an idea of the numbers at 10pm on Monday evening” while one ERG insider added that they were “intensely relaxed” about the number of rebels they had signed up. Last week, members of the hard Brexit group put down four amendments to the taxation (cross-border trade) bill due to be debated on Monday evening, aimed at halting the customs plan announced by May at Chequers nine days ago. The level of support they attract will draw intense focus, particularly if the number significantly exceeds the 48 required to call for a vote of no confidence in May’s leadership of the Conservative party. May’s leadership has been precarious since she unveiled her proposed new Brexit negotiating strategy at her Chequers residence and detailed it in a white paper last week. It prompted the resignation of Boris Johnson and David Davis from the cabinet, as well as the departures of Baker and a string of more junior ministers. ...Reports at the weekend suggested that about 40 of the 48 MPs needed had lodged no-confidence letters with the chairman of the party’s backbench 1922 Committee after May had indicated that the UK was prepared to sign up to a “common rule book” for food and goods after Brexit. There is a belief in Conservative circles that a no-confidence vote in May will have to be called by Wednesday this week as there will otherwise not be time to hold it before parliament breaks up for the summer on Tuesday 24 July. To win, the prime minister has to win over half of the Tory party’s 316 MPs, and if she does, another no-confidence vote could not be held for 12 months. https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jul/15/theresa-may-faces-rebellion-from-brexit-hardliners-in-customs-bill-vote ...May attempted to face down would-be eurosceptic rebels by warning on Sunday that if they sink her premiership then they risk squandering the victory of an EU exit that they have dreamed about for decades. A party meeting last week looked to have snuffed out talk of a confidence motion challenging May’s leadership, which would require 48 Conservative members of parliament to initiate, and 159 to win. https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-eu/parliament-vote-to-reveal-extent-of-anger-over-mays-brexit-plan-idUSKBN1K514U

My take on recent events: (in part informed by the FT's Big Read last Friday):
 - The hard Brexiteers have the 48 MP votes to launch a leadership challenge but (as of now) are far from the 159 needed to succeed. Unless this changes, a challenge is unlikely;  - that said, May's Brexit plan is decidedly unpopular with Conservative voters. If it's voted in Parliament, it will have a hard time. Labor won't help, as they want elections. The Lib Dems will probably support the plan, but they are too few. The Scottish National Party is the wild card - they may well support the plan in exchange for some concessions (e.g., a definite second independence referendum after Brexit), but their numbers may not be enough neither.  - yet I don't see a Tory politician willing to challenge May. It begins to dawn on them all that Brexit would be quite a dislocation, and no one wants to be carrying the red wooden box (where the ministers traditionally  carry government documents) while this unfolds. This is why Johnson and (perhaps) Davis left - to be able to say later "Brexit is a disaster because the government did not follow my ideas". Don't see any Tories supporting a Labor no-confidence vote either, as they would be branded "traitors" and the outcome would be worse for them than under May's plan.       - so under what circumstances may May leave before Oct 1: (1) resignation: if Parliament (or the EU) reject her plan, she may well have had enough. No confidence in my proposals - find someone else to clean the mess, please. Probability: 5% (2) A no-confidence vote in Parliament: some in SNP or Lib Dems may support Labor if they propose a vote. After all, Labor would probably need a coalition with one of them (or both) to rule in case of elections. This, however, has to happen quickly, by end-July, to meet the Oct 1 deadline. Probability: 3%

Review in light of recent cabinet resignations, now we are 7 months into the 10-month question window since my original forecast (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/633203). My original forecast had the following assumptions:
(a)(b) p(May resigns freely or dies) = 0.01; thus YES, CONSERVATIVE.
(c) p(leadership challenge) = 0.30; if so, 50% of NO, 50% of YES, CONSERVATIVE.
(d)(e) p(Tories lose working majority within 10mth) = 0.03; if so, almost certainly YES, LABOUR.
... and if none of the above, May remains PM through to October. My review in May (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/731309), 5 months into the 10-month window, had the following assumptions:
(a) p(May resigns freely, or dies) < 0.01; thus YES, CONSERVATIVE.
(b) p(leadership challenge) = 0.12; if so, 50% of NO, 50% of YES, CONSERVATIVE.
(c) p(Tories lose working majority within 5mth) = 0.01; if so, almost certainly YES, LABOUR.
... and if none of the above, May remains PM through to October. And what is happening now? News is obviously focussed on the defection of the "big Brexit" advocates Davis and Johnson after the recent Cabinet agreement advocating close ties to the EU after Brexit. However, that same agreement has mollified the (probably greater number of) relatively pro-EU. Does this mean that May is more, or less, likely to face a revolt? And is any revolt more, or less, likely to succeed in forcing a leadership change? WILL THERE BE A LEADERSHIP CHALLENGE?
Tory leadership challenges can (as I understand it) can only be launched once a year. So, for the purposes of this question, the May challengers get only one bite at the cherry. Thus they are unlikely to launch a challenge until they are reasonably sure of having the numbers (or at least reasonably sure that the numbers are not going to get any better for them). Some numbers around pro-Brexit Tories contemplating a leadership challenge?  (All are my "best guess" ...) Less than 48 members (p= 0.10) -> insufficient to launch a leadership challenge.
48 to 100-ish members (p= 0.60) -> could launch a challenge, but would certainly lose, which would be self-defeating.
100-ish to 158 members (p= 0.25) -> within spitting distance of winning a challenge and might consider launching a challenge then gathering enough support to win a close ballot.
159 or more members (p= 0.05) -> will launch a challenge ASAP, and be confident of winning. The 100-158 bracket will more likely than not launch a challenge (p= 0.65).  The perception may well be that, though the odds of tipping May are not good, they are unlikely to improve within the next twelve months, so better to strike now rather than give the appearance that May is "getting away with it" with her attempt at a soft Brexit.  However, they are unlikely to win (p= 0.30). Putting this together ...
10%: Weak support, no challenge possible.
60%: Weak support, challenge deferred pending better chances.
11% (0.25 * 0.65 * 0.70): Moderate support, decision  to launch challenge, which is unsuccessful.
5% (0.25 * 0.65 * 0.30): Moderate support, decision to launch challenge, which is successful -> YES, CONSERVATIVE.
9% (0.25 * 0.35): Moderate support, decision to NOT launch challenge.
5%: Strong support, successful challenge launched -> YES, CONSERVATIVE. Overall, that is 10% that May will fall to a leadership challenge in the near future. WILL THERE BE A VOTE OF NO CONFIDENCE? A SUCCESSFUL ONE?
If the pro-Brexit Tories sense that they fail to have the numbers to launch a leadership challenge, or if they launch one but then fail (combined p= 0.90), they may instead offer to support Labour in a vote of no confidence ... which will only need 3 supporters.  One one hand this is LIKELY, because it only requires 3 of the 315-odd Tories to defect.  This is much easier to arrange than having 49 Tories supporting a challenge, or 158 Tories voting to dump May. On the other hand, this is UNLIKELY because this is card is more effective as a threat than being used in play: a VoNC (if sustained) would result in an election that Labour would almost certainly win, and the would result in an outcome (from the Brexiteers POV) that is far less desirable than May's current proposal. Given May seems like the sort to NOT give in to threats, if 3 Tories defect to support a Labour VoNC, May is likely to stare them down, and regain the House's confidence within the required 14 days. So, the question really is - if May is NOT overthrown, what is the chance that 3 Tories will support a Labour VoNC ... AND then continue to withhold confidence from May until the government falls ... AND have the election held before 1 October??  Best guess I have is 4%, in which case -> YES, LABOUR.

Most of the comments seem to be focused on (a) do enough Conservative MPs want to get rid of May (b) do enough Conservative MPs dislike May's negotiating position for Brexit.  What seems to be missing is what would be gained by the Brexit dreaming MPs by changing the PM? As May has realised is there is no Brexit possible that would not cross her red lines, they simply contradict each other. Its not a matter of what people want to do by shear force of will power, some contradictions are simple contradictions. The Irish border status is enshrined in an International Treaty that has been ratified by referendum. The UK government cannot just walk away from the treaty, Mrs May has made it a red line that she will stand by the treaty. The Brexiteers say are prepared to walk away from the EU without a deal and trade on WTO terms. If they do that they will have to follow WTO rules. One of these rules is that every country is required to ensure that it has secure customs borders. So the UK (which currently is not even a member of the WTO) and the EU therefore cannot continue to have no border between Ireland and the UK. To have the current Irish border arrangement requires that both sides are in the same Customs Union and have identical rules (a Single Market). So simply put, the red lines of being outside a Customs Union and Single Market between the UK and EU are not compatible with the status of the Irish border as described by the Good Friday Agreement.  Unpicking the Good Friday Agreement is not a job that any candidate for UK PM looks to be up for. The main UK Parliamentary Parties are currently playing a game of bluff. The majority of MPs recognise that Mrs May is very weak and that Brexit is going very badly. For almost all of them their objective is to find a way out of the Brexit promises and red lines that will damage themselves the least and put the blame for Brexit failure on other people and hopefully other political parties. Getting rid of Mrs May in the next 12 weeks would not help any of them, because that would risk the people seen to be getting rid of Mrs May as the people who were stopping the great Brexit deal that is repeatedly promised to an increasing disbelieving public.  The Brexit voting public are also hoping someone or something will kill off Brexit. The polls show hardly anyone expects Brexit will bring them any benefits, but the polls also show that few Brexit voters want to admit they were wrong to vote for Brexit.  So the main Brexit supporting MPs are sticking to the line that only the most extreme form of Brexit is really Brexit and that any compromise is not true Brexit. They know that this would be very bad for the economy and that it would probably take 15 or 20 years for the UK to adjust. The "have cake and eat it" deal with the EU is most unlikely (and always was). WTO rules would be bad - assuming that the WTO still exists. They know it. So they want Parliament to block Brexit. Specifically they want the Labour Party to block Brexit (obviously it would need the support of a few Conservative MPs or for the DUP to withdraw its support for Mrs May). Their reasoning is that in a year or two they can claim that Brexit would have been great if only the Labour Party had not been so undemocratic as to block the will of the people.  The Labour Party and the anti-Brexit Conservatives can see that the Brexiteers want them (the Labour Party and anti-Brexit MPs) to be blamed for preventing the glorious Brexit the public were told about, so they are not willing to fall into that trap.  Mrs May's (and David Davis's) strategy seems to be to give the appearance of having negotiations with the EU, without making any progress or even discussing option that are feasible. If this goes no until January or February 2019 there will no time to agree any bespoke deal. Then the options will be to go over the cliff or accept a deal that can take existing structures (i.e. the EEA, Single Market, EFTA Court, the Four Freedoms etc.) or just remain in the EU. Parliament would not support jumping off the cliff. The choice would be the EEA/EFTA option that is a compromise, but that the Brexiteer MPs have already said would be worse than staying in the EU or actually staying in the EU. Logically staying in the EU would appear to be the sensible option, but clearly logic has little appeal to the Brexiteers. At this point the blame game really cranks up. Was it the Brexiteers misleading voters as to what was possible? The EU blocking the UK by not offering them a "cake and eat it" Brexit? Was is anti-democratic Remoaners? Was is Mrs May and David Davis being incompetent in the negotiations?   So I think Mrs May will be kicked out only when its clear her version of Brexit cannot be agreed with the EU, but its obvious that there is no time for the UK to choose a new PM, adopt a new Brexit strategy and get that agreed with the EU. This is why Mrs May is desperately asking EU governments to press Barnier not to just reject her latest complex unworkable iteration of a plan, but to keep pretending to negotiate until time has run out.

Mrs May has made her Brexit plan (if it can be referred to as a plan) more difficult by appointing Javid to the Cabinet Brexit group as he does not support her ideas. I am not sure if he does not support the Mrs Mays's Customs idea because (like the EU and almost everyone else) he does not think it workable, or because he is now a hard Brexit supporter. 
In one sense it Mrs May's Customs options are irrelevant, because they have already been rejected as impractical (magic thinking) by the EU. While Mrs May insists that the border with Ireland will remain as it is, and that the UK will be doing free trade with 3rd countries once outside the EU, it appears to be impossible to see any way to achieve her objectives. 
There is now a three way split in the Conservative Party and any one of these groups could force Mrs May out. The Hard Brexit group insists on nothing that looks like a Customs Union (and Single Market) with the EU. It has no solution to the Irish Border (except possible scrap the Good Friday agreement which created the open border).
The Soft Brexit group see the solution as staying in Customs Union and Single Market with the consequence of not having 3rd party free trade deals (but they could do deal to give services access to 3rd countries).
The Rump group want some leadership and a practical solution found to Brexit. As the Brexit negotiations fail to produce any progress the Rump might decide a new leader is needed. 
I detect a hint that the Hard Brexit group are preparing their excuses for the failure of Brexit. Failure in their eyes would be to deliver a Brexit that did not have 3rd country trade deals, but if the choice is between the free trade deals (aka "getting a packet of crisps one day") and scrapping the open border and screwing up trade with Europe (aka "a three course dinner today") the Rump would prefer the "three course meal". The Hard Brexiteers are threatening to vote against a final Brexit Deal that does not given them what they promised (but that is impossible to deliver). This would allow them to claim that Parliament had betrayed Brexit and that if Mrs May had only done what they demanded the (impossible) Brexit they said people voted for would have happened. In other words they are trying to save their credibility for after Brexit when it fails to deliver. Getting rid of Mrs May would not help them, if one of the Hard Brexiteers were PM there still would be no way they could deliver Brexit as outlined by them. 
One of the many ironies of Brexit is that the Hard Brexiteers sold Brexit as "bringing back power to Parliament", to avoid giving Parliament any of power over a EU deal they claim that the referendum was very clear and all voters understood very clearly the issues such as the Irish Border, Customs Union, Single Market, 3rd Country Trade policies etc and as it was all so clear that Parliament does not need to say if the final deal is any good or not. If everyone knew exactly what they were voting for in June 2016, how is it that 23 months later the Cabinet can't agree what deal the UK wants with the EU? If it was so clear to the voters then, why is not known by the Cabinet today?  I think the danger to Mrs May is no longer from the Hard Brexiteers (about Conservative 60 MPs) or from the Soft Brexit Group (about 20 Conservative MPs) but from the Rump who must be starting to panic as it is becoming more likely that Mrs May is incapable to getting any EU agreement at all.  Interestingly the Conservative Party Conference takes place 30th Sep to 3rd Oct. If nothing has cleared the Brexit log jam by then, Party Members could press for Mrs May to go. As the party members are very firmly at the Hard Brexit end of the party (compared to MPs and voters) the member could insist Mrs May goes, while the Hard Brexit MPs want to Mrs May to stay to take the blame for a botched Brexit.

A new poll (see link below) offers an interesting insight into how voters react. Research suggests that Populist supporters tend to be vote according to emoticons rather then be influenced by facts, they also appear to value attributes such as loyalty to their "tribe".  Liberal supporters tend to values facts and logic more highly and vote for policies.  Wales voted to Leave the EU in the Brexit referendum, but ICM finds that in the last year expectations as to the success of Brexit have declined quite sharply. ICM also makes the point  that Leave voters  both Conservative and Labour "stick" to their party regardless of changes to their parties position on Brexit. Thus Conservative Leave voters are planning to continue to vote Conservative even though the expectations of the benefits of Brexit are less than they were, while Labour Leave voters are planning to continue voting Labour even though Labour is slowing moving toward a softer version of Brexit (a Brexit not worth having according the Brexiteers). The contrary presumably also applies; people who did not vote for Brexit are less tribal and are more likely to switch parties to ones that match their views on Brexit. If this is indeed true it would suggest that Remainers and Soft Brexit supporters are far more likely to switch to parties that have these policies, than Leavers are likely to switch to Hard Brexit parties. So any party that advocates a Hard Brexit is likely to end up with only that party's core Hard Brexit supporters (e.g. Conservatives who support a Hard Brexit). While any party that advocates a Soft Brexit (in the Single Market/Customs Union ) or No Brexit is likely to keep its traditional tribal supporters (e.g. Labour Leave voters) but attract additions supporters who prefer its policy. (e.g people who have voted Conservative but don't like Brexit).         If this is true the rational thing for all parties to do to get the most votes would be to have a policy of Soft Brexit. (I am allowing for the facts that Leave won the 2016 referendum, and that few voters for Leave have admitted they have changed their mind. The passage of time and demographics is likely to have given anti_Brexit supporters a lead before the next General Election, plus the referendum brought out Leave voters who do not normally vote).  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-politics-43230062

Having agreed a deal on Phase 1 of Leaving the EU it has become clear that Mrs May is not able to get the Brexiteers to accept it. Since then the Brexiteers have been insisting that during the implementation period the status quo would not apply to the way that new EU migrants would be dealt with, that the UK would expect to make (not just negotiate) trade deals with 3rd countries, not be subject to all EU rules and laws, and even that the UK might want to not have an implementation period.

Dateline 2-6-2018 As star-crossed British Prime Minister Theresa May gets weaker and weaker, hardliners within her Tory party may finally try to pull the plug and replace her with one of their own with the aim of negotiating a sharper split from Europe. It would be a risky move, given the Tories’ slim majority in parliament. If the “soft-Brexit” wing of the party doesn’t go along, it could unintentionally open the way for rival Labor party leader Jeremy Corbyn to become prime minister. “Hard-Brexit” Tories may still take the gamble, betting that at the end of the day, the party will stick together rather than clear a path for Labor. The Tory position will become clearer after a fresh round of cabinet deliberations on Brexit this week, after which point May’s days could well be numbered… Why it matters for the UK: Any Tory replacement for May would ultimately seek out a harder line on Brexit, prolonging uncertainty in the UK – which could prompt a mass corporate exodus from London – and threaten to permanently split the Conservative party. Why it matters for Europe: A rockier Brexit process isn’t good news for the continent either – the UK is scheduled to leave the EU in March 2019, with or without a negotiated deal, and a failure to agree to future economic relations before then would disrupt a commercial and financial relationship that is, still, critical for both sides. -- Signal <signal@eurasiagroup.net>

The broad history of Prime Ministerial changes in the UK in the post-war era have gone as follows:
General Elections (1945; 1951; 1964; 1970; 1974; 1979; 1997; 2010) i.e. 53% of times
Internal party challenges (1990; 2007) i.e. 13% of times
Voluntary resignation owing to scandal, crisis or ill health (1955; 1957; 1963; 1976; 2015) i.e. 33% of times
It should be said from the off that as there have only been 15 Prime Ministerial changes in 72 post-War years, the base rate of any change is c.21% with the split for three above categories (GE, internal challenge, voluntary resignation) coming in at c.11%, c.3% and c.7% To deal with the first category, a General Election is next scheduled for 2022 and the Conservative Government look very unlikely to want to call another, thanks to their experience in 2017. In any case, holding an election halfway through Brexit negotiation is something that probably all parties would want to avoid. The likelihood of a General Election this year is therefore c.0%
(Base rate is 28% [20GEs in 72 years]; Of those only 4 happened in the middle of an election cycle [1951; 1966; 1974 and 2017] taking us down to 6%; And those 4 were always because the Government saw the opportunity to improve its position - something which the current Government does not see - taking us down to more or less 0%. An internal party challenge requires the support of 48 Conservative MPs under party rules. This is not impossible given that some MPs are currently unhappy with various aspects of Government policy: http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-plot-tory-mps-grant-shapps-brexiteers-remainers-conservative-cabinet-leader-latest-a7985861.html
Nevertheless, an ousting in the midst of important international negotiations seems to rely on the negotiations themselves being rejected by Conservative MPs. For reasons of rebelliousness of Parliament over Brexit-related legislation, I think this is a higher prospect than in a normal year. I will give it a c.70% chance. The final category of scandal, ill health etc. forcing a change is much more difficult to predict. The one clear case of ill health forcing a Prime Minister out (Churchill) happened to a legendary smoker and drinker at the age of 81. Theresa May is not in a comparable position. A "black swan" scandal on the level of Suez Crisis, Profumo Affair is inherently unlikely and more or less impossible to forecast. What does seem entirely plausible is a failure of Brexit negotiations forcing her to stand down. It does look though that currently negotiations are progressing (Phase 1 has been passed; the EU is looking likely to concede on the UK's main demand for financial services access). Nevertheless, a high risk remains, which I will put at 70% (20% higher than an average year) Conclusion:
Base rate of 21%; 
Extremely low likelihood of a GE this year (-11%) =11%*0
High chance of an internal party challenge (-1%) =3%*0.7
Reasonable chance of a voluntary resignation (-2%) =7%*0.7
Therefore 93% chance of no change in 2018; 94% chance given discounting of November and December. Given my discounting of a General Election, all chance will go to a new PM from the Conservative Party.

The Labour Party would end up in government as a result of an election, so part of one's analysis of this Q should be to consider how likely it is for an election to be called before Oct 2018. The Fixed Term Parliament Act makes snap elections relatively difficult to call. In 2017, Theresa May sought the approval of Parliament to hold a snap election. The reason for this was that she was confident that her party could significantly increase its majority.  Now, however, the Conservative party is weak, with a lost majority and poor poll performance. If the last snap election was called because Theresa May was confident, the situation now is the inverse, meaning she will be highly disinclined to call a snap election herself. Additionally, to call 2 snap elections in such quick succession would be perceived as especially weak.  Thus, I believe a Labour PM is the most unlikely outcome. I have not set it at 0 on the chance that  she feels forced to call a snap election due to combined pressure from the public, the opposition, and her own cabinet. This still seems extremely unlikely as this would require the support of Conservative MPs, who have other means of removing May.  It would be much easier for Conservative MPs to remove May via internal party mechanisms, as an election runs the risk of losing more ground to Labour, the worst case scenario for the Conservative Party. How likely is it that May will be replaced by another Conservative MP? Relatively, but potentially not before Oct 2018. After poor performance in the 2005 general election, Blair was replaced by Brown in 2007. This, coupled with the fact that a leadership contest would further destabilise Brexit negotiations, makes the idea of a leadership battle BEFORE the date stated somewhat unlikely. Yet, arguably May's Government are more unstable than Blair's in 2005. May does not have a majority in Parliament, and is relying on the support of the DUP, a relationship that might become more complicated as Brexit negotiations continue (Irish border issue).  There are also various sections of Conservative MPs cross with May's decision to call the 2017 snap election. There are a few big personalities that one could see replacing May (Rees-Mogg, Johnson, et al). The last leadership election was muddled, with candidates standing down until May was the last person standing - all before the end of the first stage of Conservative leadership process. Potential usurpers have plenty of ammunition to argue that May is incompetent, illegitimate, and that they should be leader instead.   0% other party as the UK has an entrenched 2 party system.

Base Rate Analysis:  Tories did not perform well in last election. But moderates have a lot of doubts about Corbyn and return to power of militant/momentum/whatever.  And removal of sitting PM by own party is, in modern times, still unusual.  Less unusual might be a break with the DUP leading to a new election. But that would be unlikely to produce an outcome that favored the DUP. Specific Case: Despite ongoing Brexit turmoil, May still looks like the least unfavorable person to have in Number 10 today. Removing her via intraparty means would risk alienating a Tory bloc and/or the DUP, running the risk of another general election that could bring Corbyn to power. Conclusion: Unlikely that there will be a new PM before 1Oct18. Pre-Mortem. Assume forecast is wrong. What did I miss?  Willingness of certain  Tories to risk Corbyn taking over in order to reach Number 10 via an intraparty battle.

The question is what could lead May to stop being PM. She could become ill or sick of the job (5% chance?). She could loose the support of the DUP and no longer command a majority in Parliament or she could be overthrown by hard line Brixiteers or hard line Remainers in the Conservative parliamentary party (15% to 25% chance). But a walkout by the DUP would not result in any conceivable majority government that would  be more likely to support DUP views, so it is difficult to see any advantage to them in walking out. Replacing Mrs May with any Conservative that actually had any strong views of Brexit would cause more obvious fractures in the Conservative parliamentary party - a strong hard Brexit PM would not be supported by enough MPs to push a hard Brexit through parliament, a strong soft Brexit or no Brexit PM would not be supported by all Conservative MPs, but with support from most of the other parties in parliament they could command a majority for a soft Brexit or no Brexit. If DUP or Conservative rebels (of the hard or soft variety) meant May did not have a majority it would be bound to lead to calls for a general election, and the last general election did not go well for the Conservative Party or for the Hard Brexit cause so Conservatives will want to avoid another one. So my view is that faced with a big decision in order to get enough votes in Parliament Mrs May will have to listen to the soft Brexit Conservatives more than the Hard Conservatives, and that no anti-May group would really gain by throwing May out.  If May is thrown out she is more likely to be replaced by another Conservative without a general election (and then possibly a general election would follow, but Mrs May would not have been directly replaced in a general election), So it difficult to see how May could be directly replaced by October 2018 by a Labour PM.

So how will May's premiership end, whenever that might be?
(a)  Her death?
(b)  Her resignation from office (and probably from parliament) of her own free will?
(c)  Losing a Conservative leadership spill, or being forced to stand down by colleagues?
(d)  Losing an election triggered by having the DUP withdraw confidence?
(e)  Losing an election triggered by losing a series of by-elections? [Can anyone else think of any alternatives??] Theresa May is a 61yo female in a first world nation.  Her baseline risk of death in the next 9.5 months is about 0.003 (0.3%).  The increased risk imparted by her diabetes and stressful job is probably balanced out by her vigorous physical hobbies and lack of children (motherhood is hell).  If she dies, the certain outcome will be "Yes, someone from the Conservative Party." Resignation of her own free will is unlikely, not in the next 10 months anyway.  It is conceivable that a long-serving PM might stand down to allow an orderly succession, especially to a colleague at the same level as part of a power-sharing arrangement (Blair-Brown in the UK; Hawke-Keating in Australia).  I can't see May is in that situation.  If she does freely resign, the certain outcome will be "Yes, someone from the Conservative Party." If there is a Tory leadership challenge, then either she wins ("No") or she loses ("Yes, someone from the Conservative Party"). The Conservative-DUP agreement is necessary for May to maintain confidence.  Labour's position in the polling is significantly stronger than it was at the time of the June election, and Labour would benefit massively from (yet another) return to the polls.  Another election would very likely lead to "Yes, someone from the Labor Party".  The DUP know this, and while it is possible (but unlikely) that they would withdraw confidence in order to play hardball with the Government, even then I think they would rather form a more favourable agreement to restore confidence with the Tories within the following 14 days than go back to the polls. The Conservative-DUP agreement, assuming it remains intact, needs to lose 7 seats in order to lose a working majority for confidence and supply.  In the UK, by-elections come at the rate of about 3-5 per year.  For the Government to lose their majority, there would have to be 7 by-elections, in seats that are currently Tory-DUP held, that are then lost by the incumbent member.  Using some rough estimates, the chance of this happening AT ALL in the next 10 months is about 10%; the chance of it happening _7_ times is effectively zero. So let's put some numbers on this ...
(a)(b)  p(May resigns freely or dies) = 0.01; thus YES, CONSERVATIVE.
(c)  p(leadership challenge) = 0.30; if so, 50% of NO, 50% of YES, CONSERVATIVE.
(d)(e)  p(Tories lose working majority within 10mth) = 0.03; if so, almost certainly YES, LABOUR.
... and if none of the above, May remains PM through to October. Main things I need to keep my eye on ...
*  How likely is a Conservative leadership challenge?
*  If a leadership challenge, are how likely is May to win?  How likely are any other contenders?
*  If an election is held, how likely is Labour to be able to form government after?
*  Are there an abnormal number of by-elections being held, that is, enough to threaten the Government majority?

First let me qualify this by saying that nothing really is predictable in UK politics nowadays! Although Theresa May is in a generally weak position following the loss of her majority in the last election, inertia is the most likely outcome, even looking 10 months out.  In forming this prediction, I made the following observations:
- The DUP are likely to do just about anything to prevent a Labour government, and even if they did pull the plug on the confidence and supply arrangement it's not a sure thing that Labour would get in (it has been decades since the last left-wing Labour government, many in England will never vote for Corbyn, SNP took over a lot of the old Labour vote in Scotland). Despite this, I don't rule out another crisis within the Tory party, new elections, and Labour gaining enough seats to form the next government. I think however that it would likely be some kind of coalition/supply (Lib Dem, SNP likely partners as they would be keen to put the brakes on Brexit) rather than an outright majority. I put the probability of any of these events leading to a Labour PM at around 20%.
- Infighting in the Tory party appears to have dampened down a little bit, but it's still there in the background. Grant Shapps' campaign to oust Theresa May didn't really go anywhere and it appears he actually got quite a bit of backlash from it. I put the probability of some major event happening that causes Theresa May to be replaced by a colleague in the Tory party at around 30% (the DUP's votes are still agiven).
- I would assign a probability <1% to someone from a party other than Labour/Tories, although if decimal places were allowed this would not be zero (if something it possible, it is to some small degree probable)
- Considering this all in the bigger picture, I am then left with a probabilty of about 50% (just under if we are being exact, see previous point) that Theresa May remains PM up to and on 1 October 2018. www.fxtradesurfer.com
